greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The bottom entry in the absolute difference triangle of the divisors of n.
comment: Note that if n is prime then a(n) = n - 1.
Where records occurs gives the odd noncomposite numbers (A006005).
First differs from A187202 at a(14).

It is important to note that at each step in the process, the absolute differences are taken, and not just at the end. This sequence is therefore not abs(A187202) as I mistakenly assumed at first. [Alonso del Arte, Aug 01 2011]
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: a(18) = 4 because the divisors of 18 are 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 18, and the absolute difference triangle of the divisors is:
mathematica: Table[d = Divisors[n]; While[Length[d] > 1, d = Abs[Differences[d]]]; d[[1]], {n, 100}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Aug 01 2011 *)
program: (PARI) A187203(n)={ for(i=2,#n=divisors(n), n=abs(vecextract(n,"^1")-vecextract(n,"^-1"))); n[1]}  \\ _M. F. Hasler_, Aug 01 2011
a187203 = head . head . dropWhile ((> 1) . length) . iterate diff . divs
where divs n = filter ((== 0) . mod n) [1..n]
diff xs = map abs $ zipWith (-) (tail xs) xs
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Aug 01 2011
